subsection.title: Power Functions

assemblage.title: Power Function
assemblage.p: A function of the form f(x) = k(x)^p where k and p are nonzero constants, is called a power functionpower function.

subsection.p: Examples of power functions are V(r ) = \frac{4}{3}\pi (r)^3 ~~\text{ and }~~L(T ) = 0.8125(T)^2. subsection.title: Long Run Behavior
subsection.p: While power functions do not in general have to have integer exponents, these will be the types of power functions we are most interrested in. In particular, we will look at the graphs and long run behavior of power functions with integer exponents. By long run behavior of a function we mean the value the function approaches as the input x goes to infinity or negative infinity.

statement.p: Recall that the graph of f(x)=\frac{1}{x} and g(x)=\frac{1}{x^2} are given by: graphs of the two basic reciprocal functions Identify the long run behavior of each of these functions.

example.solution:
Let's begin with the long run behavior of f(x) . Looking at the graph, we see that as x goes to infinity (i.e. as we move farther to the right on the x -axis) the output values of f(x) are getting close to 0. Similarly, as x goes to negative infinity (as we move farther to the left on the x-axis) the output values of f(x) are also getting closer to 0. We write this as \text{as}\ \ x\to\pm\infty\ \ f(x)\to 0.
By identical reasoning as above, we also have that \text{as}\ \ x\to\pm\infty\ \ g(x)\to 0.
